artefact: PAYE forms: P45, P46, P60, P11D

artefact.overview: What you need to do with P45, P46, P60, P11D forms - and how to get replacements

parts.title: P45 and P46
parts.body:
You’ll get a P45 from your employer when you stop working for them.

Your P45 shows how much tax you’ve paid on your salary so far in the tax year (6 April to 5 April).

A P45 has 4 parts (Part 1, Part 1A, Part 2 and Part 3).

  1. Your employer sends Part 1 to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) and gives you the other parts.

  2. You give Part 2 and 3 to your new employer (or to Jobcentre Plus if you’re not working).

  3. Keep Part 1A for your own records.

By law your employer must give you a P45 - ask them for one.

You don’t have a P45

If you’re starting your first job or you’re taking on a second job, you won’t have a P45. Your employer will need to work out how much tax you should be paying on your salary.

They may give you a P46 to fill out.

parts.title: P60
parts.body:
Your P60 shows the tax you’ve paid on your salary in the tax year (6 April to 5 April). Your employer must give you a P60 if you’re working for them on 5 April.

You’ll need your P60 to prove how much tax you’ve paid on your salary, eg:

  • to claim back overpaid tax
  • to apply for tax credits
  • as proof of your income if you apply for a loan or a mortgage

Your P60 can be on paper or electronic.

parts.title: P11D
parts.body:
Your employer sends a P11D to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) if you get any ‘benefits in kind’ (eg company cars or interest-free loans).

The P11D records how much each benefit is worth.

Your employer will send HMRC a P11D if your earnings, including the value of company benefits, are at least £8,500 in the tax year (6 April to 5 April).

Your employer will usually give you a copy of the P11D. They don’t have to by law, but they must tell you what’s on it.

parts.title: Lost PAYE forms
parts.body:
Lost P45

You can’t get a replacement P45.

Instead, your new employer can give you a P46, or send the relevant details about your finances to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC).

Lost P60

You can get a replacement P60 from your employer.

P11D

You can usually get a copy of the P11D from your employer. If they can’t give you one, you can contact HMRC for a copy.

details.description: Includes company cars and paying tax on employee benefits
Information about starting up and running a business in the UK, including help if you're self employed or a sole trader.

artefact.title: Reporting your tax code as wrong
Keeping your pay and tax records
